ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I really appreciated the unique format of the class. I also enjoyed meeting the speakers after extensive reading of their work.
I wish that the instructors had led the class more actively, as I took the course in part because I wanted to hear their perspectives and insights.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Awesome guest speakers, the opportunity to go to a small dinner with each speaker, and having classmates from different schools.
Getting to know a diverse group of Yale graduate students and interviewing/meeting a very interesting range of thinkers/actors.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think it would be helpful if we did the readings for each speaker the week before the speaker actually came to visit. I realize that travel is difficult to arrange in the winter, but having the readings and class discussion fresh in our minds would make the visits more valuable. I also thought it was strange that we talked so much about Thomas Berry but never actually read anything by him. I know it's hard to cap courses, but this one was too crowded for a good seminar discussion. The discussion also was not managed well - sometimes people would raise their hands and wait their turn to speak, but others would jump in without doing so. The result was that the most assertive class members often took the floor and left no space for their peers who did not wish to interrupt. As a woman, I felt on more than one occasion that I made a comment that was ignored, only to have the same idea repeated by a male classmate.
It would have been great to have a final class (after our speaker series ended) for synthesis/reflection.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
Why did you take this course?
Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I had a great group. I was brought to a deeper understanding of the literature through discussion with my group. I also met students in schools outside of my own.
It was challenging to agree on interview priorities/questions, but very illuminating to work through this with others.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
